subject: Re: [junit] TestNG 4 and Data Providers
msgSnippet: ... It may be at 45 degrees, but it s certainly not completely orthogonal. As JB pointed out, when a normal test fails, all you need to know is which one; the
messageBody:
On 10/13/05, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
> Still, I think this is a different topic. Having a meaningful failure
> message is orthogonal to whether this test method received parameters or
> not.

It may be at 45 degrees, but it's certainly not completely orthogonal.

As JB pointed out, when a normal test fails, all you need to know is
which one; the rest of the data should be there. When a parameterised
test fails, however, you need to know which parameter was passed in
that failed.

When you do parameterised tests in JUnit 3, you typically override the
runTest method - this frees you up to set the name, as it won't be
used for the reflection-based test running. I always make the test
name something meaningful, based on the parameters coming in. A least
effort approach would be to include the _number_ of the parameter
(e.g. parameter set 5 of 10).

> Once in a while, I will bother adding a failure message in the assert, but
> most of the time, I don't and if there's a failure, I need to dig in anyway
> so the stack trace is usually good enough to get me started.

Yes - with the data as well. Without the data, you need to work out
which one failed. Maybe the test failure file you output is good
enough here, but maybe not.

--
"Software is too expensive to build cheaply"
Robert Watkins http://twasink.net/ robertdw@...
